title: About
text:
Hi, nice to meet you! I’m Lucas.
I am a student of biochemistry at Heidelberg University, currently working as a visiting student at the Shalek Lab in Boston.
My interests lay in using computatinal approaches to better understand cellular biology in the context of diseases and cellular dysfunction (see also Work). I am especially fascinated by omics technologies.

title: Work
text: My goal is to contribute to the understanding of the driving biological mechanisms of diseases in order to develop new cures, with a special fascination for our immune system. title: Gzip is all you need? - Cell type annotation with a meme algorithm
text:
Recently, this tweet, talking about this very creative and interesting paper (Jiang et al. 2023) blew up on twitter. To keep it short, the authors demonstrated that a simple .gzip compression of text-based data, in combination with a kNN classifier performed as well on text classification tasks as state-of-the-art natural language models (here: BERT). Especially in cases of small to medium-sized datasets (where the training data does not suffice to sufficiently fine tune large language models), the minimalistic algorithm (XXX lines of python code ) performed extremely well. Intriguingly, it does not use any tuning parameters. This is of course somewhat embarassing1 for our multi-million dollar, Big Tech-backed deep learning models, trained on millions of GPU hours. Probs to the authors!
In recent history, the life sciences have somewhat blindly followed the latest deep-learning hype (to be fair - very often with great success), by transferring their favorite model type onto a biological question of choice (see Table 1), typically protein design or -omics.
Of course, this has also been the case for our latest hype algorithm!!! The paper was almost immediately adapted to the prediction of molecular properties of small molecules (Probst (2023), see Github and Twitter). This raises the question - can we throw also our latest hype algorithm on omics data?

title: Compile LaTex with github actions
text:
I love LaTex. Although it was shown that writers using LaTex are both less productive AND make more mistakes (Knauff 2014), it is still so much more fun to code a LaTex document than writing in a dull Word Document. In addition, LaTex is extremely lightweight and never crashes, even when writing long documents with many high-quality figures that bring my laptops’s memory to the limit when using Word. - especially while writing on important thesis projects, I appreciate everything that is not an additional stress factor.
I’d like to share a few tricks that helped me to
I recently started to use github.com as my default cloud storage for my LaTex documents. Other than being a great storage/cloud backup for my documents, this has also the great advantage of being highly trackable.




References

Knauff, Jelica, Markus AND Nejasmic. 2014. “An Efficiency Comparison of Document Preparation Systems Used in Academic Research and Development.” PLOS ONE 9 (12): 1–12. https://doi.org/10.1371/journal.pone.0115069.

title: Your birthday might kill you!
text:
I recently attended a very enjoyable open-air performance of Shakespear’s Macbeth. Given my limited knowledge about the piece and English literature in general, I did the thing that most of the peers in my generation would do and I read the Wikipedia page on William Shakespeare in advance. Unfortunately, I did not get past the first paragraph as it immediately caught my eye that Shakespeare died on his birthday. Very tragic!1
But is it though? After thinking about it for a while, I came to the (for me) surprising conclusion that we might be statistically prone to die on our birthday… In this post, I will share with you my finding that in a model world, the most probable day of your death will be your birthday. So watch out!

title: Your birthday might kill you!
text:
Modeling
Don’t believe me? Let’s start with a simulation.

Prior assumptions
In order to facilitate the computations, I will first create a model simpliefied model world with the following assumptions/simplifications:

For every day in your life, it is equally likely for you to die.

This assumption is clearly not accurate (for humans). For example, infants or people above age 50 have a significantly higher chance of death than people in their twenties (see the official actuarial life table of the US social security office). However, it is probably relatively safe to assume that the likelihood to die is more or less smooth and changing slowly, i.e. we would not expect any sudden changes in the likelihood of death within a an age cohort. As we will essentially compare the likelihood of death per day within the same year, our model is still valid. We also dismiss any seasonal changes (e.g. heat deaths in the summer or flu in the winter) that might affect the results.

Planet MB-15640423

In order to make the observed trends more significant, I will assume for now that we observe life on a planet with very short year of only 10 days. However, the observed trends will also hold true for any other length of the year, but might not be as obvious to see.
To further simplify the computations, we also assume that our planet does not have any leap years.


The model
Based on these assumptions, we can create a simple simulation: We first define a function life that simulates the life of a single individual: For every day, the individual either survives or dies with a 5% probability \(p_{death}=0.05\). The function life runs until it reaches the day of death of the individual and then returns the number of days that the person survived (days_lived). We repeat that for a few thousand simulations (individuals) to get enough sampling.
We can figure out whether the individual died on their birthday or not by using the remainder (modulo operation) of the division \(\frac{\text{days lived}}{\text{length of year}}\). E.g. if a person died on their birtday, they survived 0, 10, 20, 30, 40… days model world. When dividing by the length of the year the remainder will always be zero (Mathematically speaking: \(y\times \text{length of year} \equiv 0 \:\text{mod}\:\text{length of year}\) for \(y \in \mathbb{N}^0\)). If a person dies one day after their birthday, the fraction \(\frac{\text{days lived}}{\text{length of year}}\) will have the remainder 1 and so on…
Implementing this model in python (see hidden code cells) and plotting the results looks like this:


Code
# Import modules
import numpy as np 
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt


# Parameters
np.random.seed = 15640423

plot_params = dict(
    marker='o', 
    linestyle='', 
    color='#45B39D', 
    markeredgecolor='k'
)

N_individuals = 10000
length_of_year = 10
probability_of_death = 0.05




Code
def life(probability_of_death: float = 0.05):
    """ Simulate length of a life given a constant 
    probability of death every day """ 
    
    days_lived = 0
    while np.random.random() > probability_of_death: 
        days_lived += 1
    return days_lived 


# Simulate N_individuals lives 
days_lived = [life(probability_of_death) for _ in range(N_individuals)]

# Get day of year (0-birthday, 1-day after birthday ...)
day_of_year = [dl % length_of_year for dl in days_lived]

day, counts = np.unique(day_of_year, return_counts=True)

rel_to_expected = counts/np.sum(counts)

fig, ax = plt.subplots(1,1, figsize=(7,4))
ax.plot(day, rel_to_expected, **plot_params)

ax.axhline(1/length_of_year, 0, 1, 
           color='#cccccc', 
           label='Expected by equal chance')
ax.set_ylabel('Observed deaths/Expected deaths')
ax.set_xlabel(f'Day relative to birthday in {length_of_year}-day year')

ax.annotate('Birthday', xy=(0, rel_to_expected[0]), xytext=(5,0), xycoords='data', textcoords='offset points', va='center', ha='left')
plt.show()





Observed number of deaths at a day X after birthday divided by the expected number of deaths if we assume that it is equally likely for a person to die on any day of the year.




What we see is that in our simulation/toy example, it is almost 30% more likely for an individual to die on their birthday than we would expect by random chance. Furthermore, the likelihood to die on day 1, 2, 3, … after ones birthday steadily decreases. But why?

title: Your birthday might kill you!
text:
The real world
Birthday effect

title: Your birthday might kill you!
text:
Intuition
The underlying concept is straightforward. On our birthday, we inevitably face an equal or greater likelihood of mortality compared to any other day. To elaborate, consider a scenario in which we analyze the lives of a whole population of individuals, as we did in our simulation. While most individuals would survive their actual birth date, regrettably, there exists a nonzero probability that someone might pass away precisely on that day, thereby decreasing the total population. Consequently, when the probability of death remains constant, fewer individuals, on average, will add to the count of deaths on the day following their birthday, and so forth. As the birthday will always be the first day in every new year, there will always be more individuals available at their birthday than any other day. This leads to the fact that in a full population, more deaths would occur on birthdays than any other day.

title: Your birthday might kill you!
text:
Conclusion
In this blog post we have looked at the somewhat surprising phenomenom that we are probably more likely to die on our birthday than any other day.
I believe that the provided workflow can also be adapted for other scientific endevaours and especially computationally approaches: First, we observed an interesting phenomenom. We then started to build up an intuition for the problem by creating a model world, in which we tried to clearly articulate the underlying assumptions of our model. And finally, when we felt more comfortable with our intuition, we put in the effort and derived a more theoretically grounded model.
